[Portrait]Gaffgarion
[Dialog]You would use the princess as bait
to regain the Stone?
I would not expect such cunning
of a man of the cloth.{END}

[Portrait]Ludovich
[Dialog]You've some gall to speak, sellsword!
It was you who let them escape!{END}

That I don't deny, but it was
not my task to stop them!{END}

[Portrait]Cardinal Delacroix
[Dialog]Still your tongue, Ludovich.

We will hand Princess Ovelia over to
Lord Dycedarg as promised. That
much serves us both.
But it is no concern of mine if those
who know the truth of her kidnapping
live. I had no hand in it.
Be that as it may, the thieves who
stole the gem are now with them.

If we use the princess to lure them
out, we get two birds-and one Stone.{END}

I won't deny the truth of it.
But such a plan has risks.{END}

Your reputation would not cast you
so craven.{END}

I am -cautious-, Your Holiness.


A soldier does not live to become old
and gray charging onto the field of
battle unawares.{END}

Very well. I will see that every
possible precaution is taken.

And let us sprinkle a trail of crumbs
to ensure they find our snare.{END}

A prudent move. The maid's the perfect
bait to lure them to us.

I'll assume responsibility for the rest.
Far better me than -him-.{END}

How -dare- you!{END}

Very well. I shall leave the matter to
you, Gaffgarion.{END}

Your Eminence, you jape, surely!{END}

Go with my blessing.{END}

The Stone is good as yours.{END}

Your Eminence, you cannot mean
to trust this to a man like -that-!{END}

I trust things to those who can be
trusted. Men who fail me time and
again are rewarded in another way.{END}

Y-Your Eminence, wh-what are
you doing!?{END}
